alert.note: Alert for Western Prince William Sound (Alaska) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued September 08 at 11:33AM AKDT by NWS Anchorage
info.description: ...FLOOD WARNING FOR SNOW GLACIER-DAMMED LAKE OUTBURST IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 AM AKDT MONDAY... * WHAT...Flooding caused by a glacier-dammed lake outburst is expected. * WHERE...the Snow River through Primrose Campground and Kenai River through Cooper Landing to Skilak Lake. * WHEN...Until 1000 AM AKDT Monday. * IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:25 am AKDT, river gauge reports indicate rises in water levels from a glacier-dammed lake outburst across the warned area. Flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly, especially near the Snow River and Kenai River. - For Snow River near Seward: At 10:00am the stage was 12.5 feet. Flood Stage is 16.0 feet. Forecast: A crest around 14.2 feet is expected around 10:00pm Saturday. Impacts: At 12.5 feet: Floods gravel area just downstream from railroad bridge. Water starts to flow over Primrose Road. Low spots on this road (near the boat ramp) are approximately 1 ft lower than the adjacent lake bank. Water up to the railroad tracks in several places between railroad mileposts 14.5 and 18.0. -Oct 2020 At 13.0 feet: The end of Primrose Road will be impassable to small vehicles. This will impact access to residences as well as the campground. At 14.2 feet: Garages along Primrose Road will begin to flood. For the Kenai River at Cooper Landing: At 10:00am the stage was 11.6 feet. Flood Stage is 13.0 feet. Forecast: A crest around 15.7 feet is expected Sunday Morning. At 12.5 ft: Water starts to flow over Primrose Road on the southern end of Kenai Lake. At 14 ft: Properties along the Sterling Highway miles 48-50 begin to see water in their yards. USGS gauge house adjacent to Cooper Landing bridge will begin to flood. Bottom of wooden walkway at boat ramp starts to be submerged. At 15 ft: Quartz Creek Campground boat ramp submerged and water encroaches campsites that are located next to the lake. Water should start to approach foundation level of buildings along Sterling Highway miles 48-50. North Cooper Creek Campgrounds begins to flood. Water in slough at mile 54 will encroach the Sterling Highway. At 16.5 ft: Many houses and businesses along Sterling Highway miles 48-50 will begin to flood. Water should also start to encroach houses built along Primrose Road. Quartz Creek and North Cooper Creek Campgrounds will be underwater. Water will also be over the Sterling Highway at mile 54. - Inherent uncertainty in initial glacier lake volume will result in varying crest height and timing. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles.
